div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: OPPOSITION OF MARS 1907.
div.p: The Astronomical world at largo is through out this month of July, busily engaged observing and photographing the surface of the "ruddy planet' with which romance hall 90 familiarised the "man in the street." The planet whose distance from the earth at the most_unfavourable opposition is some 61 million miles, was on the 6th July but 88 millions as compared to only 36 millions in 1909, and we may confidently look for confirmation or the reverse of Bohiaparelli's observations which were the subject of so much technical discussion at the last favourable opposition of 1892.

The possible existence of a race of beings with intelligence, the so called "canals," tha great probable age of Mars and its remarkable period of revolution, all tend to make the most callous deeply interested in this raddy globe which revolves abouts its axis in bat a few minutes more than doen the earth, and is the nearest of all the planets whose orbits lie outside our own.

Last May the Lowell expedition to the Andes sailed from New York with the object of cha yrving the planet from the most suitable ki ality in that part of the world, and amongst other well known men of science Prof. odd, Mr. Slipher and Mr. A. Q. Isle socom; many the expedition in the capacities of din stor, expert in photography, and chief mecha: ician, respectively.

Tho gh Schiaparelli was 80 emphatic as regard the existence of the "canals", a word which is caused no little misunderstanding, it in only recently that the camera has revealed their doubted existence. For many years, since 1 177, these front markings, with which the imagination of man has run riot to use the expression of Baikie-were disputed and argued upon by all and sundry, but each success Yo opposition, with improved appliances, 1 as added fresh proof of the truth of Schiapı rolli's wonderful powers of observing, and added more weight than ever to the household word in astronomy, that what is seen is he result of two powers, instrument and observer.

These canals appear to radiate from central res" and the modern conclusion is that Mars has an atmosphere such we know it, that the dark regions are marshy tracts, the polar mpe ice and know, and the reddish portions desert land out up by waterways which carry water to the ones to which the population dusters to benefit by its accumulation. (Baikie.)

There is no doubt that these dusky lines vary much in hue as the polar caps go through the effect of climatic change, and it is held that the change is due probably "to the consequent alteration in colour of vegetation with the increase or decrease in water supply (Lowell.) Miss Agnes Clerke says here soon and ise meet there must be water and the origin of the Rhone from a great glacier is faroely more evident than the dissolution of the Martian ice caps into streams and pools' '.

Though to the amateur, observations of this planet, one of the most interesting in the solar system, are somewhat disappointing as the disk requires great instrumental power and considerable experience in this type of observation, still the sight of the beautiful disk of raddy light low down in the South Fast portion of the sky after sunset in the constellation Sagittarius, in such a perfect Atmosphere as this country affords, well repays the trouble of preparation with no matter what instrumental power the observer posester, and though probably but few have at their disposal telescope powerful enough to resolve ay best the frost prominent features, yet the right is wonderful in the extreme

There is no celestial body which will be the subject of so much care and trouble for some time to come, if we accept the expected mr appearance of the well-known Halleif's comet which is due to pass perihelion in March 1910 and whose last appearance in 1835 m the abject of so much discussion, and the world, all wait impatiently the results of the observations during this month which are carried on in all parts of the world.

div.head: Council of Ministers
div.p: The Council of Ministers will meet at San Stefano on Monday under the presidency of Bontros Pasha Ghali.

div.head: A Palee Rumour.
div.p: "Al Zaher" contradicts the report that a member of the Khedivial family, rosiding at Naples, recently committed suicide owing to losses on the Bourse. That newspaper states that the Khedive bns financially assisted the Prince

div.head: The Eld Case
div.p: Yesterday the Belgian Consular Court at Cairo appointed Dr. Voronoff to make an expert enquiry on the wounds, contusions and other lesions which Mrs. and Mies Bid state that they are suffering from in consequence of & train coming into collision with their carriage.

div.head: Ministry of Public Instruction
div.p: The Finance Commission has approved the budget of the Ministry of Public Instruction for the scholastic year of 1907-1908. They have also confirmed the nomination of Ahmed Bey Kamha as sub director of the Khedivial Law School, and the retirement of certain employés

div.head: Goal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and July 11th 664,580 tons of coal were imported into Egypt of which 361,772 tons were Welsh, 102,460 New castle, 107,853 Yorkshire, 52,092 Scotch, and 40,678 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the local importe totalled 623,460.

div.head: Brindiel Mall
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi (P. and Q.S.S. service) will be made up at the G.P.0, Alexandria, on Monday afternoon at a quarter past three for ordinary correspondence, a quarter past two for registered correspondence, noon for money orders and insured articles, and soon on Sunday for parcela

div.head: Culde to Alexandria .
div.p: The Alexandria Municipality has published a useful little guide to the City and Museum of Alexandria. The author is Professor Breccin, the Conservator of the Alexandria Mason and he is to be congratulated on his work, which fills a long-felt want. The antiquities of the city are very thoroughly dealt with, and modern Alexandria is also well described.

div.head: Abyssinia to Khartoum.
div.p: Lieat. Sandford, Royal Garrison Artillery from Aden, arrived at Khartoum on the 29th May, having completed a journey through Abyssinia via Djibouti and Adis Abebe, then to Godljam and Paraku on the Blue Nile. This journey was taken merely as a pleasure excursion, Lieutenant Sandford having utilized part of his leave for this purpose.

div.head: New Alhambra Theatre,
div.p: It is hoped that the plan of seats and boxes of the new Alhambra Theatre will be ready to-morrow and that it will be possible to open the box-office for the booking of seats on Monday. The prices have not yet been advertised by the management. The Lombardo group has been meeting with great shoes in Cairo and we can anticipate a most enjoyable inaugural evening on Wednesday with Myslu.

div.head: Disciplinary counsel.
div.p: Athind meeting of the Disciplinary Council We hell to continue the examination of Mohamed bey Ziadi, alleged to have given his daughter in marriage to a prisoner of Tours HOW undergoing sentence of 20 years. The evidence of Hassan Eff, Abou el Nasr, Guindi Ef Growbrial and of several other witnesses was heart and eventually the case was adjourn: ed by the Court until this morning

div.head: A Dastardly Revenge
div.p: Consequent to quanell between two students of Al Azhar University one of these waited until the other had retired to bed and agreed to sleep, when he approached him silently and set fire to his clothing. The yells of the victim of this brutal entourage attracted several of his comrades, who speedily extinguished the fire and saved the youth's life, though not before he had been very badly bumad. Harsan el Goheni, the author of the crime, has been arrested.

div.head: French National Fate.
div.p: Tomorrow on the Q in of the French National Pate, a grand / festival champetre, will be held at the Eldorado Theatre and Garden, which are now being gaily decorated and arranged for illumination. Pour bands will be in attendance and there will be a liberal display of fireworks. In the theatre the usual variety entertainment will be given and there will also be a bullet entitled "The Animated Dolls." The entertainment will be concluded with the "Marseillaise" sung by all the troupe and led by the vivacious Belle Nitajo.

div.head: Memphis
div.p: The appeal made on behalf of the work which the British School of Archeology proposes to undertake in excavating the Ancient Peyptina capital at Memphis has received considerable publicity in the home Pres. All that remains of the great city is a shapeless mass of ruins, though as late as the thirteenth century a considerable portion remained above ground. It was founded thousands of years agy, and the wonder is that any trace of it remains when we consider how completely very much younger cities have disappeared from the face of the earth. Englishmen, mi guardians of Egypt's destinies, owe a special day to civilization in guarding the treasure entrusted to their hands, and these buried trees may hare important lessons for the world of today

div.head: LAUNCH OF THE "CAIRO EGYPTIAN MAIL 88 CO. BOGHOS PASHA'S SPEECH. Caretto's Speelal Servios.)
div.p: London, Friday. The "Caine," sister ship to the S.S. "Hello polis of the Beyptian Mail Steamship Company Ltd was launched at Goran at ip.m. yesterday under excellent weather condition from the shipbuilding yard of the Fairfield Shipbuilding and Engineering Co., Ltd., the ceremony being performed in the presence of a large number of spectators by the Counters of Crower. Unfortunately Lord Cromer was unable to attend the ceremony..

The "Cairo is $45 ft. long, 60 H 3 ins. broad, t. in depth from keel to shelter deck, and of 12,000 tons To register. The propelling machinery consists of three sets of Panon' turbines having an aggregate of 18,000 h.p. The turbines are arranged in the usual manner, the high-pressure turbine in the centre and the two low pressures in the wings. All three shafts run at 340 revolutions per minute. There are seven deeks in all, and they are connected by an electric lift. Accommodation has been arranged for 266 first-class And 180 second-class passengers. The road is equipped with the Thermal-break system of ventilation, a refrigerating plant for the preservation of provisions, and a Clayton fire extinguishing service. She in, in short, in every detail similar to the "Heliopolis" whose description you have already published.

A large and distinguished company sat down to a most excellent luncheon, at the conclusion of which Boghor Pasha made a memorable spareh, in English. People", he wid, "not well B uainted with Egypt might be astonished at
Liis alluding to the great prosperity of the country at this moment, when it was passing through a financial crisis." The crisis, however said Boghes Pasha, was due to reckless Bourse

speculation and too numerous companies being launched without regard to prudence. It was a mistake to suppose that the crisis affected the whole country. It did not affect in any way the wealth of Egypt, which consisted of cultivable land of marvellous fertility, the production of all crops and especially cotton.
Much Amusement has been ended by the reporter referring to Boghoa Pasha as an Arab millionaire, and Financial Adviser to the Khedive

div.p: London, Friday. Replying to Mr. Rutherford in the House of Commons Sir Campbell Bannerman declined to give a day for the discussion of Egyptian affairs and said that very fall information was given to Parliament yearly in the ConsulGeneral's report.

div.head: GOLD SHIPMENTS TO EGYPT. COPE WAITEHOUSES OPINION.
div.p: Mr. Cope With House has addressed the following letter to the editor of the Journal of Commerce and Commercial Bulletin of New York:

Sir. It is conceded that the Beyptian situation is playing an important part in international credits. The facts, however, do not seem to be generally understood. The manufacturers using Reyptian cotton, in New England and North Carolina, have purchased over 185,000 tales (500 lbs.) since September ist. If the payments had been mode to Alexandria direct the export of $13,000,000 in gold would have been generally known. This is equally true of about $4,000,000 willi was paid, during practically the same period, for the expenditures incurred by American visitors to the Nile. The combination of two such items as the purchase of a staple, required for important industries with far-reaching commercial effect, and the sams expended on exhuming the dead and guaing at pyramids may tend to excite a smile. But so far as the exchange account is concerned the purpose plays no part.

The Egyptians buy nothing to balance the American count. It is not even a commercial interchange by a triangular movement. except that the payments are made through London or Paris. Now the months during which gold has hitherto been sent to Egypt since September, 1902, are from August to February, both inclusive, but only September, October and November appear in each of the five years. There was no shipment at all later than November in 1905. There was none in February, except in the single year 1904. The value and quantity of the cotton crop during this quinquennial period did not vary greatly prior to September 1, 1906

After the contrata for the Assouanneer voir had been signed, extensive preparations were made in Europe to take care of an inOras in cotton which was estimated at a million bales. It was supposed that this might be regarded as a normal addition to the maps of 1897-98, 1899-1900 and 1901-02, where the exports exceeded 1,800,000 bales. No such - sult, however, followed. The crop prior to this last one never even shed the earlier figures in amoun but represented a greater valoa. They were sold for $85,000,000 (1902-03 3102,000,000 (1908-04), 889,000,000 (1904-05) and 298,600,000 (1905-06). But the importa in gold did not correspond to the amount thes due to the planter. About one half of the Egyptian crops are purchased by England, one tenth by the United States and two fifths on the Continent. While $88,750,000 was remitted, in 1908-01, for a crop valued at $109,000,000,only $17,100,000 was sent to Alexandria to move crop of 898,600,000; kod there was no import of gold at all from December 1, 1906, to September 1, 1906, a period of aine months. The total gold balance paid to Egypt for the crop of 1905 06 was less by 20 per cent than the amount remitted in that single month of October, last year, which marked a well-remembered epoch. The precipitate action of the Bank of England and the Bank of France has left an indelible record on the price of American securities. It is now officially admitted that the remittance to Egypt of $22,500,000 was the cause and not a coincidence. From September 1, 1906 to February 1, 1907, gold shipments had already reached the highwater mark of 842,050,000, and now, on June 15th, s further sum of $1,250,000 has been withdrawn from the Bank of England. It is die in Alexandria on June 22, but there is nothing to show what England, or, for the matter of that, France, Germany and Switzerland have sent since February, or what Finance bills still remain unpaid

Although extensive repairs, coating over $1,050,000, have been made in the Axona Dam, there is always a measurable ground for anxiety from August 15 to about September 20. that a dangerous Nile may impair the cotton top in the Delta. The Dam, of course, does not control a dangerous flood; on the contrary, it constitutes a new peril, but it is surprising to learn that it was never intended to increase the cultivated area of Egypt. "I wish Again to explain that the main reason why the Assouan Dam and the Assiut Barrage were constructed, was not, as is often supposed, to bring a fresh area of land under cultivation (Lord Cromer. Park. Rep. 1906, p. 8). This supposition has been continuously entertained by many people, since 1898, and seemed to be well founded on explicit statements, to that effect, during the last nine years in the London press. It is probable that although there will be no substantial increase in either quantity or value of the erop of 1907-1908, still, practically the same amount as this year will be required to buy it. Now why did the gold export of $38,850,000 (1908-1904) fall to $700,000 (1905-1906), to rise to as much more than $49,050,000 since September, 1906, a has been sent to Alexandria since February 11 I 1904 Beypt took $3,500,000 in February, and here international credits are confronted by a shipment in the middle of June. This movement of gold has no more to do with speculation in cotton" than an Illinois corn crop, in December, with curb quotations for a Cobalt mine. There are 1,147,824 Egyptian owners of land. As 82,000 cotton states were scheduled as having been protected against the cotton worm, it is endent enough that gold might be widely distributed and hoarded to an amount exceeding $50,000 in a single year, with only silver in the Treasury and the Cairo banks void of billion of both sorta.

The Anglo-French entente of 1904 is to sponsible for the relief to the gold movement in 1905. "The redundancy of sovereigns was accentuated by the liberation in January, 1905 of large amounts in specie held by the Chie de Dette which on being handed over the Government were banked and thus tributed to sell the market
Abos £2,000,000 ($10,000,000) were shipped abroad to Balandand India in December am Jantar (report 1906, p. 103). This war certainly hela precision, but the gold

is evident enough. On January 1908, there wa 343,870,000 in specials the special sub-tray, under the control the representatives of the six general powers of isligare given for January 1, 1900 but as there could have been so domination may be safely Armed that the largeur of specie amounted to no less than $18,000,000 I VA "bersted." "banked, welled the market rere and the fourths of in ($30,000,000, having been paid to the planter $10,000,000 was shipped to England and India. It was the direct result of the cele Pleated interviews het een Edward VII a M Dela

Therefore, the shipment of gold to Alex and I che mouth of June aurice matt, when there is the prospect of another europe with at $190,000,000, tebe picked in August. How far the United States may be called upon for gold involve other factors. But in no event should the financial writers In the American press allow the responsibility to shift to Ameries or describe the more went as a speculation in cotton. High finance huita lw for the navigation of the upper air as well as operations nearer the ground The liberation of dependant sovereigns, which having swelled market TOTO in Hop England and Praes, me hack Wee a bridal wave is the following October, se Gaelyen. Prunk loans forward and back and across the British Channel, may be amazing performance on the high top of the argue de Paris et d'Angleterre, but the governors of the Earpen banks should be made to provide their own net, or pay for the broken bones of the performers who come to grief.

Dr. Carl Peters, who was plaintiff in the section for libel which has been engaging the attention of the German public, met with an accident when he was in Egypt Sitting in the saddle in a mounted crowd one evening. and engaged in contemplating the Sphinx, he Www to severely kick his neighbour's mount that his kneecap was smoked to bits. In the Cairo hospital they were for amputation at once. The patient absolutely refused. He insisted that he would pull through, and he did. He lay for months with his leg in plaster of Paris, bet he limped away on that leg, and Limps on it still.

div.head: A CRICKETEER FOR EGYPT
div.p: Mr. Meyrick Payne, from whom so much is expected in the Oxford and Cambridge match is entering the Eeyptian Government service. He is an old Wellingtonian A writer in the "Daily Mail, describing the qualification of the varsity elevens, remarks "Mr. Meyrick Payne, is for the most brilliant bat in the match, possibly second only to Mr. Jersop in contemporary cricket. He can get going at the outset and though trifling uncertain, it seems as if all bowling comes alike to him. A year has only ripened his sloring proclivities since his memorable feat in the last university match. It is a great loss to English cricket that he should be following Mr. W. H. B. Byns into the Egyptian service. There is no parallel to the desire of a wicket-keeper, good enough as a freshman to be chosen for Gentlemen . Players at Lord's, to resign the gloves in his year of captain. But he considers his batting is thereby affected."

div.head: HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: A prominent Indian Monomsk.who recently made a journey on the completed sections of the Hejaz Railway has sent his impressions to an Indian contemporary. He says that the line is remarkably well built and dwells upon the excellent work done by the troops employed on the railway. There are special trains for the carriage of material and victuals and there is never any difficulty in procuring drinking water. A valuable coal mine has been discovered at a distance of ten miles from Chiffs, and other mines have also been discovered in the same neighbourhood. He adds that the sacred milway will mach Meccs before long

div.head: MEDICINE IN ANCIENT EGYPT
div.p: There is much evidence in inscriptions and manuscripts that the ancient Egyptians pre tied medicine and surgery extensively. Probably their practice was based on little knowledge of Anatomy. Rach physician treated only one or two dinnen. The siek were exposed in palio places so that others who had suffered similarly might tell them of helpful remedies. Dina of the eye were best understood and received both medical and surgical treatment. The most important medical mano

eript found in Egypt is the Papyrus Eben written 3000 B.C. and discovered 6 Memphis Dinosa, According to the Baypins, due to the anger of some deity, the mult of the triumph of evil in its struggle with good, an idea which is still very general throughout Africa and Asia and which st some time has been prevalent in modified forms in almost every mo "Records of the Pail.

div.head: The Money Market
div.p: There has been quite a glut of floating credit in Lombard Street this week, which continues in spite of heavy repayments to the Bank. This plethora of money is likely to be further increased to-day by the dividend payments. Yesterday no more than 1 to 2 per cent could be obtained for short loans, while three months bills were easy at 8 percent.

Egypt has not taken any more gold this week, but in the best-informed circles it is now anticipated that when the present crisis is passed, further imports will be made in order to assist in restoring things to a normal position. The prospects of an excellent cotton crop, and the high prices now obtained for yarn make it certain that a considerable quantity of gold will be required for Egypt in the autumn. Besides, inasmuch as we shall probably ere long need still higher quotations for Egyptian cotton, in view of the possibility of & short American supply, the amount of gold required next winter will surely be considerable.

On the other hand, there are some who say that since only a small portion of the nine millions taken for Egypt last autumn was returned, it is reasonable to suppose that some, at least, of the balance will be available for use in the moving of this year's crop

The Bank return this week shows a heavy shrinkage in the reserve as the result of the half-yearly currency requirements. The amount of £1.097,000 was received from abroad, but £1,432,000 in coin and £768 00 in notes went into home currency, and the reserve there tore £1,103.000 lower. at £23,681,000, the proportion to liabilities being down 4.39 per cent. to 39.34 per cent. Last year at this date the reserve stood at £24,968,889, and the proportion at 41.23 per cent.
The price of har gold is unchanged on the wook at 77/97.

div.head: Silver
div.p: There has been a revival of purchases for the Indian Bazaars, and the market has been very fim. The quotation for bar silver has improved to 31, 1/16.

div.head: The Stock Markets
div.p: Since our last the big financiers connected with affairs Egyptian have experienced a week of more or less anxiety, as a result of the difficulties created by the suspension of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio. So great is the confidence of the Egyptien investing public in Sir Emest Cassel that as soon as it was known that he and his friends were interesting themselves in the affair, a great deal of the anxiety regarding the ultimate settlement disappeared ; nevertheless, it is obvious that there was much work to be done before this much-to-be desired result was accomplished. The final arrangements were come to yesterday for the voluntary liquidation of the Cassa, and the thanks of the whole backing and financial community in Egypt, as well as those who desire to 100 thou proliant unsatisfactory 1 position liquidated, are due to Sir Ernest Cassel and his colleagues for the masterly way in which they have overcome the present difficulties.

These astute financiers, as we informed you in our cable to day, have placed around quarter of a million, or more, if necessary, at the disposal of the Cassa to enable the Bank to meet its present liabilities, so that the process of winding-up voluntarily can be carried out quietly, and the sold securities liquidated without haste. This is eminently satisfactory, and now that this very serious matter is cleared up, we may hope that we have seen the worst of the crisis. Of course, it must be proven that there will be still more wreckage to be dealt with, but none of it is likely to prove of serious import, and is mainly connected with smaller companies, who have been trading beyond their means. With the prospect of a bumper cotton crop, and increasingly high prices, referred to above, we may look forward to the future with confidence, secure in the knowledge that the unhappy crisis through which we have been passing is but temporary, and has not the potentiality to seriously check the course of Egypt's prosperity. The country is sound in every respect and the lessons of the present difficulties, if taken to heart, will prove wholesome. Genuine investors have had a splendid opportunity, of Requiring some of Egypt's sound securities at well below their intrinsic worth, and the amount of money which has been found for the purpose both here and in Paris runs into very large figures and has been pleasant surprise to those behind the scenes

The Bourse speculating punter must not again be allowed to resume the reckless gambling so much in evidence last winter, and the indiscriminate formation of new companies will also have received a wholesome check.

The announcement that the Cask difficulties had been satisfactorily settled had a good effect upon the stock markets generally yesterday, and the tone became much more cheerful. There was an appreciable amount of investment buying in several departments, and prices were firmer.
Today there is little business passing, but the tone is on the whole favourable.

div.head: Consols
div.p: The market for gilt-edged securities has failed to maintain last week's advance, the downward movement being helped by the report that a new loan for the County of Middlesex was about to be issued. Consols are now quoted at 84 for the account.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: The leading international bonds have been quiet for the most part, but quotations have been well maintained. Russians show little change, the Fives being quoted 82] and the Fours 737.
There was some demand for Japanese yesterday, the Fours (1905) improving to 847 and several other stocks

div.head: Home Ralls.
div.p: After the temporary improvement recorded last week, home railway shares have agaia been neglected, and have been one of the dullest markets in the house. This is somewhat surprising, taking into consideration the splendid series of traffics published this week, and the imminence of the half-yearly dividend announcements. It is customary to lay blame for most of this world's ills upon the weather, but there can be no doubt that the present unseasonable conditions have not been without effect upon these shares.

Yesterday the market was ignored for the greater part of the day, but towards the close there was some hardening of prices. Today the tendency has been somewhat irregular, and business lisas been restricted.

The traffic returns are very gratifying. The North Western, for instance, report an increase of £16,000, which follows a gain last year of £21 000, the Midland add £11,700 to last year's increase of £21,000; the North Eastern have an increase of £13,000 on top of one of £12,100; and the Great Northern show & gain of £14,000, against an increase of £3,700 twelve months ago.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The American section opened very firm on Monday, thanks to strong support from New York, and substantial advances were recorded. The upward movement was speedily checked, however, and for the greater part of the week the tendency has been much easier. The unsatisfactory reports regarding the prospects of the cotton crop, and uncertainty as to the monetary situation, largely account for this weakness.

More cheering advice came yesterday, and the tone improved correspondingly, but business was almost at a standstill in consequence of the Independence Day holiday in Wall Street. As a rule closing prices were about over parity. Great Northern Preferences were ap 2. Milwaukee 2, and Unions.
Today the tendency has again been favourable. Unions are in request at 144 5.

div.head: Mining.
div.p: Kaffirs were dull enough during the first two days of the week, the Paris settlement causing a good deal of nervousness. The tone is now much better, however, the rumours of failures in France having proved groundless. div.head: Revue Commerocial.
div.p: SIR R: SLATIN INTERVIEWED.
Reuter's representative has had an inter view with General Sir Rudolf Slatin (Inspector General of the Sudan), who is on a short visit to this country.

Speaking of the position in the Sudan he said: "The position of affairs is entirely satisfactory, financially and politically. The revenue shows an annual increase, and this without having recourse to increased taxation In fact, on the contrary, we are trying om best to reduce taxes where possible.
The people generally are satisfied, and if as sometimes happens, new laws have to be • enacted which go against their traditions, they
realise that they are for the public good, and cheerfully sıbmit.

One of the most important signs in the Sudan is the remarkable increase of popula tion, and by this I do not inean the removal of people from other regions, but the great increase in the number of children, which is åt inost hopeful sign for the future of the country. The people are most anxions to have their children educated, and a satisfactory proof of their confidence is that they are sending so many that the applications are more numerons than our schools are able to accept. The Gordon College is already bearing good fruit, as the Government is being supplied there with land surveyors, &c.'

Dealing with the native situation, Sir Rudolf said : "The tribes are peaceful. Of course, inter-tribal questions and jealousies arise when it is necessary for the Government to keep · der ; but there is nothing to give rise to any anxiety. With regard to the Senussi movement, this has very little influence in the Sudan. It has a certain weight in Egypt, but it is chiefly in Darfur and the west. In the Sudan it is practically nil."

Asked about the recent manifestation of the Pan-Islamic movement, Sir Rudolf said that it was a very dificult question to discuss, but added that he did not consider the people of Egypt or the Sudan were fanatical.

"One must always remember," he added, "that they belong to a different religion from our own, and that in Egypt, particularly people who are discontented with the Government, are always ready to use their religion to stir up the population against their rulers."
On the subject of general development Sir Rudolf Slatin said:

"New commercial stations have been opened, one leading to the Blue Nile and one on the Baro, and trade is beginning to flow from Abyssinia to the Sudan by this means Of course, at the beginning it is slow, but great development may be looked for. We are on good terms with the Abyssinians. although occasionally there is trouble with raiders who are outlaws in Abyssinian ter ritory.

"As regards water communication, we are improving the rivers in every way we can We continue to clear the sudd, and dredger have been ordered for deepening the chan nels. The Atbara-Port Sudan Railway is working most satisfactorily, and trade along this route is increasing.
"We are now engaged in building a bridge over the Blue Nile at Khartoum and extend ing the railways through the fertile country between the White and Blue Niles.

"There is no necessity to construct a rail way connecting the Sudan with Uganda whil there is a splendid waterway to Gondokoro We must, of course, have a line of communica tion from north to south, but there is n necessity for a Cape to Cairo railway on thi section while we have better and cheape transit by boat."
"With regard to motor traffic in the fa away districts of Bahr-el-Ghazal and Souther Kordofan, roads are being made and improve so that motor lorries can be employed." .

Concerning the situation at the Lad Enclave, Sir Rudolf said that the relatior between the Anglo-Egyptian and Congo Fre State Governments were friendly, as the latte had evacuated the territory claimed by th former. ("Financial News.")
COMPANIES IN EGYPT.

div.head: "TO EMPIRE VIA DENSHAWAI."
div.p: * (From The New Age.) Just about a year ago a party of British officers got mixed up in a village row at Denshawai, in Egypt. They had gone to amuse themselves by shooting pigeons, the domesticated pigeons of the villagers, and had apparently not been | careful to get permission. By accident an
Egyptian woman got wounded, the officers were mobbed and lost their heads, two of them ran for help while three were beaten by the crowd, and one of those who ran dropped dead.

Now it does not need a very profound knowledge of the psychology of the British officer to recognise in this incident all his characteristic bravado and stopidity. The | officers had not taken the trouble to either understand the language or the humanity of the villagers, who were treated as creatures of another species.

Consequently at the first sign of the breakdown of the formal nexus of behaviour which enables the British officer to communicate with the Egyptian village, the officers were hopelessly bewildered, lost their heads and gave way to panic.

Had there been anyone at headquarters to put the matter right by a stiff reprimand, matters would have been no more serious than a schoolboy's row with a gamekeeper. But apparently those at headquarters got even more panic-stricken than the officers, and without the excuse of the hubbub and turmoil of a riot, gave fanatic orders for arrest and trial of the riotous villagers 1 As a result four men were hanged, and eight men were flogged and some imprisoned.
On the face of it, this story sounds incredible ; one imagines there must be something more behind it. That something more, accordJing to Lords Cromer and Grey, is an Egyptian
National movement which has to be sternly suppressed.

But even granting that there is an Egyptian Nationalist movement, is there any evidence at all that the mobbing of soine stupid men at Denshawai had anything to do with it ? In fact, there is no justification whatsoever for this belief, there are no reasons, only motives, and the motives are those of bewildered fear.

Now, even if Denshawai were a separate incident, it would be a very serious matter to recognise that our administration in Egypt is so fatally wrong-headed. Whatever other conclusions we may draw, it is at least certain that out administrators, do not understand the | temperament of the people they are governing.
The question becomes, have they made any | effort to understand ? How many, for instance,
of those officials who are thrown into contact | with the people of the country can understand
their language or are versed in the etiquette of their social life?
In South Africa many Boers keep their hats on their heads when they enter a room and expectorate at leisure on the carpet. This conduct would be considered a little ontra in London.

Is it not perhaps possible our officials transgress in an equally serious manner? Is there, indeed, any adequate provision to prevent such possible offences ? T'he shooting of domesticated pigeons does not sound as if there were.

The matter, however, is by no means confined to the one incident. The Denshawai picnic is diagnostic of the most serious imperial disease-ccmplacent failure to understand. One can parallel it almost detail for detail in the incidents which occurred before the late Natal campaign ; the failure to understand, the refusal to try to understand, the sudden panic of minor officials spreading up into the central administration; the harsh measures of retribution, the imagination of a big national| ist "Ethiopian" movement. All these things were parts of the Richmond incident which precipitated the Natal campaign.

If an administration will only go on irritating a people, whom it does not understand, long enough, if it will only go on telling them they are dangerous traitors nursing nationalist dreams, that people will come to believe and act upon the Government's suggestions. The question finally is one of the possibility of zavoiding this kind of stupidity.

Empire has no meaning for a Socialist, unless it means the co-operation of autonomous units. Can we understand and co-operate with the Egyptian people and with the other alien races within our boundaries? If we are to do so it will need a very much greater effort to understand, and it will mean that our administrators sball be really compelled to study the language, habits, and customs of the people amongst whoin they are going at first hand. And this means in all probability the scrapping of a good deal of our upper-class public schoolboy machinery in favour of a school-board polytechnic-educated human being.
The time, indeed, may not be far distant when we shall be compelled to insist on the public-school coming up to a decent educational standard.

From the national point of view that is, and not their class point of view. When one reads in the Blue books that in the Denshawai hangings and floggings "all possible humanity was shown," and "the arrangements reflected great credit on all concerned," and then parallel this with a quotation from the Natal shooting correspondence where a clergyman of the Church of England certifies that the men were shot "with the utmost humanity," it is clear that the disease is deep-seated.
Unless our administrators can realise that other races and classes are human beings, and can understand them as human beings, there is no future for our Empire.
Meanwhile there are some Denshawai natives still in prison. We have made them our enemies, that is the worst of stupidity, but there is no reason why they should be kept there any longer.

We are glad to see that a petition signed by Egyptian notables was presented to the Khedive on June 28, the anniversary of the "hanging" incident; and we hope that the petition will be supported by questions in the House of Commons..

div.head: MANCHESTER GOODS.
div.p: TRADE WITH EGYPT.

It was hoped at one time, says the "Monthly Journal" of the British Chamber of Commerce for Egypt, that the financial crisis through which we are passing would not affect to any appreciable extent this branch of the import trade, piece goods dealers, as a rule, being free from any desire to purchase stocks and shares ; but the suspension of the Cassa di Sconto has quite dissipated that hope, as this establishment appears to have been in direct financial relation with various firms interested in the trade. Business during the month of June has been extremely quiet. A few small sales of cheap goods may have been made; a few orders for the season may have been booked : and that is about all that can be reported. No revival is likely to take place until the present uneasiness and want of confidence have passed away. :

div.head: PLAGUE IN INDIA
div.p: The following mortality following the out| break of plague in India is shown by figures
furnished by the India Office in reply to a parliamentary question.
In 1896 there were 1,704. deaths, but in | the following year the record leaped to 56,000.
For two years the rate of increase was almost as heavy up to 1900, when there was a lull. But it was only temporary.
During 1904 over a million deaths were recorded, and this year, for the first five months, the appalling total is 991,003.
Since 1896 five and in half million deaths have occurred.

p.hi: Ertrait d'acte de Société en nom collectif.

div.p: Suivant acte sous seing privé en date du cinq (5) juillet mil neuf cent sept (1907) il a été formé entre MM. Félix Gusman et Emmanuel Dentamaro une Société en nom collectif sous la Raison Sociale :

F. Gusman et E. Dentamaro. Cette société a pour objet l'entreprise de toutes sortes de travaux publics ou privés, études techniques et industrielles, chemins de fer, travaux hydrauliques, constructions, etc.

Elle a également pour objet toutes opérations immobilières (achats de terrains urbains et agricoles, soit pourles revendre, soit pour les exploiter; prises en location de terrains, soit pour les sous-louer, soit pour les exploiter) ainsi que toutes opérations industrielles ou commerciales.
Elle ouvrira au Caire un bureau ayant pour titre "Engineering Office and Contractors".
Le siège de la Société est au Caire.
Le capital de la Société est de cinquante mille livres égyptiennes (50,000 L.E.).
La signature sociale F. Gusman et E. Dentamaro appartient aux déux associés qui ont tous les deux la gestion de la Société. .
La durée de la Société est fixée à trois années et demie partant du 5 juillet courant pour finir le 31 décembre (1910) mil neuf cent dix.
Le présent extrait est fait en conformité des articles cinquante cinq (55) et cinquante six (56) du Code de commerce.
Pour la Raison Sociale F. Gusman et DENTAMA'RO.

div.head: EGYPT'S IMPORTS.
div.p: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY.

The following partieulars of the importa tion of agricultural machinery into Egypt are given by the " Bulletin " of the International Chamber of Commerce at Cairo. For some years the importation of agricultural machinery into Egypt has shown a remarkable development, as the figures below will prove :

... ....... 116,936 .1906 ... ... , 204,640 In 1906 the imports were derived as follows - United Kingdom, L.E. 184,223 ; Switzer. land, L.E. 21,961 ; Germany, L.E. 11,824 Ainerica, L.E. 11,439; France, L.E. 3,800 other countries, L.E. 1,387. Egypt is essential ly an agricultural country, and the Sudar appears likely to become one, so in the near future trade in agricultural machinery is bound to develop still more. At the present time ir Egypt ont of an area of nine million feddans only six millions are under crop, the remaining three million feddans will be cultivated wher the schemes of irrigation drawn up by th Government have been realised.

Schemes are also on foot for largely increas ing the agricultural resources of the Sudan and this will naturally lead to a large demand for the necessary implements. The work o education of the peasants is being carrier out by means of agricultural exhibitions on ganised by the Khedivial Agricultural Society

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Vendre il 12 juillet Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres se maintient à 8 5/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé hier de 1) S.S. 1/8. L'Unité a rationné de 1/4 à 100 8/4. La National Bank est restée invariante 19 7/8, l'Agricole à 778, la Daira Sanieha 13 1/2 et la Delta Light à 91 2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien avance de 2 francs à 684. La Banque d'Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 11%. Le lots Tores sont renseignés en hausse de 2 frames & 170

lei, le marché se maintient dans le calme et le marasme que déterminent, d'ordinaires les vacances de Juillet. Au reste, il en est de même à Londres, à Paris et dans les autres Bourses d'Occident; il n'y a done pas lieu d'attribuer cette stagnation à des causes purement locales, comme s'évertuent à le faire les splen listes qui se plaisent depuis quelque tempe à découvrir chaque matin un grammage noir à l'horizon financier égyptien. Ce qui est symptomatique et ressent tout ensemble, en dépit de toutes ces praeliotions alarmantes, c'est que les ventes volontaires ou formelles ont cas d'arroser la cote de leur poids et que les cours de maintiennent relativement ferma. De la sorte s'affirme de plus en plus l'espoir, d'ailleurs très légitime, d'ane reprise lente, mais durable, capable de fermer les plaies encore plantes dues à une crise longue mais nullement profonde provenant uniquement d'un excès de spéculation coïncidant avec un resserrement monétaire universel.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National i'et tarbe 19 5/8. L'Agricole s'est, par contre, raffermies 7 18/16. La Cassa di Sconto a été cotlo 35 nominal. Les parts de fondateur de la Société Générale Égyptienne sont remontées à 35.

Le Crédit Foncier est resté à 680; les obligations à lots anciennes ont progrerad 6 311312; les nouvelles ont faibli à 261. La Bébéar a été mieux tenue à 25 1/2. L' Allotment s'est traité : 1 15/16-2. L'Enterprise and Development a progressé à 8 1/4-1/2,
Les Jouissances Baux du Caire ont Albania 177. Les parts de fondateur Heliopolis ont avancé à 9 5/8. Les Automobiles sont tombées à 11/4-1/2 pour clôturer 18/4. Les Lots Tures ont été négociés à 160.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nanovib ont été ramenés à 15 1/8. Les Egyptian ont été pour un moment aux abords de 5 1/4 pour finir à 51/8. Les Upper Egypt ont program 2 18 16. Les National ont faibli à 2 1/2
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont avancé & 1 5. Les Oasis sont revenues à 03/8-7/16.
Le marché des valeurs étant fermé les samedis pendant la saison d'été, le prochain numéro de ootte Circulaire ne paraîtra que le lundi 15 Juillet courant.
Une assemblée extraordinaire des membres de l'Association des courtiers en valeurs d'A. alexandria est convoquée pour lundi prochain, 15 Juillet courant

A l'ordre du jour : 1'. Mesures à adopter pour le règlement des transactions en actions Bourse and Banking Co. of Egypt Ltd.: 2 Election de trois non membre du Comité en remplacement des trois membres démis. sionnaire, MM. J. Arditi, P. Agostino et D. Klat.

Un avis officiel de l'Egyptian Estates Cor informe les actionnaires que l'assemblée générale ordinaire de cette société aura lieu comme nous l'avons annoncé hier, le 26 Juillet courant, au siège social à Londres. L'ordre du jour porte: 1° Rapport du conseil d'administration; 2. Examen et approbation du bilan et de compte des profits et pertes au 6 Avril 1907. Le dépôt des titres peut être effectuée la Bank of Egypt ou L'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Caire on 1 Alexandrie.

Uno Assemblée extraordinaire, dont l'objet n'est pas désigné dans l'avis, aura lieu le même jour Aussitôt après l'assemblée ordinaire. Il s'agit, assurément, de délibérer sur la nouvelle émission d'obligations dont il est parlé dans le rapport du conseil.

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de l'Express Nile Steamers Co., qui s'est tenue hier dans Pardo-midi au siège social au Caire, a approuvé les comptes et le bilan du premier service cloud le 30 Avril 1907.
Elle a ensuite ratifié la nomination de M. P.
Boyer en qualité d'administrateur et renouvelé le mandat des censeurs, MM. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt.

Une assemblée générale extraordinaire de la North Egypt Land Co. Ltd est convoquée pour le 23 Juillet coûtant à Londres, 14 Great Winchester Street, E. C, à l'effet d'examiner et d'approuver une résolution tendant à la liquidation volontaire de cette société et de nommer comme liquidateur M. John Baker, de la maison Baker, Sutton and Co. chartered accountants.

Suivant des informations transmises de Constantinople, le mouvement de hausse qui s'est produit ces jours derniers sur les Lots turn out attribué à la nouvelle d'après laquelle les achats des grands établissements de crédit auraient lieu à l'avenir non-seulement à la Boune de Paris, mais aussi à celle de Berlin,

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS

Le 19 Juillet 1907 de 9 h. Am. alhp.m. la Municipalité procéder à la vente aux enchères publiques près du Fort Sad (Porte Rosette) d'ono quantité de 2,500 m3. environ de pierres provenant de ladite démolition.
Les pierres sont divisées en lots de 20 à 100% in3.

Les acheteurs devront paver le droit d'en chère de 1% et déposer lo 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral a la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication. Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de 10 (dix) jours sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudicataire et sous perte du dépôt de 10%
La Municipalité est libre de ne pas donner suite à l'adjudication, quels que soient les prix offerts. Alexandrie le 11 Juillet 1907.
L'Administrateur, 30628-3-1 (signe) W.P. CITATAWAY.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs
div.p: AVIS

The Administration of the State Railways has the honour to inform the Public that, with a view to facilitating the goods work at Gabbary station and in order to provide more accommodation for unloading all the inward goods during the cotton season, it has been decided, after consultation with the Alex, andria Produce Association, that during the months, October 1st to January 31st each year, the withdrawal of cotton bales at Gabbary on Sundays will be obligatory, thus making Sunday an ordinary day, on which demarrage will be collected in cases of delay.
Merchants, in their own interest as well as that of the Administration, are respectfully requested to make their arrangements accordingly.

The Administration also begs to call the attention of merchants to the fact that it will help matters considerably, if they can arrange to withdraw as much cotton seed as possible Cairc, 8th July 1907 . 30618-9-9

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Administration has the honor to inform the public that tenders will be received up to noon on the 28th August 1907 for the supply of Bundry Articles, such as feather (Dusters, Sponges, Shovels, Hammers, Zine,

Tin, Pig Load eto, according to the Specification and List, of which copy can be obtained 1 against payment of 200 millièmes, at the Central Office of the General Stores, Boula (Cairo) and at the Office of the Inspector of Stores Gabbary (Alexandris), where the standard samples and drawings may also be inspected daily from 9am to 1 p.m., Sundays and holidays excepted.

All persona desiring to take part in this adjudication must submit the samples requested in the above mentioned list, and must previously lodge in the Central Treasury of the Administration a sum of LE. 25 Twenty Five Egyptian Pounds) as a provisional deposit; the successful tenderer must increase this sum to the amount of ten per of his accepted offer

Tenders intst be accompanied by a stamped paper of the value of thirty milliemes, and Also the receipt for the aforesaid provisional deposit. They should be addressed by registered post to : The General Manager,
Egyptian State Railway in double envelopes, the inner bearing the following inscription, TENDER FOR THE SUPPLY OF
SUNDRY ARTICLES." All Tenders received later than the day and hour above mentioned will not be taken into consideration.
The Administration is not bound to accept the lowest or any offer, and reserves to itself the right to divide the order. Cairo, July 4th 1907 80696-21

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fen de l'Etat Égyptien AYIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat l'honneur d'informer le Public que dans le but de faciliter le service des marchandises à la gare de Gabbery et d'avoir assez d'espace pour le déchargement de toutes les marchandises à l'arrivée pendant la saison cotonnière, elle a décidé après avoir pris l'avis de l'Alexandrin Produce Association que pendant 4 mois chaque année, soit du 1er Octobre au 31 Janvier, l'enlèvement des balles de coton à Gabbary sera obligatoire le dimanche comme les autres jours de la semaine et qu'un droit de chômage sera perçu en cas de retard.
MM. les négociants sont dono priés dans leur intérêt ainsi que dans celui de l'Administration, de prendre leurs mesures en conséquence.
l'Administration a l'honneur d'attirer d'autre part leur attention sur le fait qu'il y aurait grande utilité ce qu'ils enlevassent également le plus possible de graines de coton.
Le Caire, le 8 Juillet 1907. 30617-9-2

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public qu'elle recevra ja qor'an 28 Août 1907 à midi au plus tard, des offres pour la fourniture de divers articles tels que plumosa 6, éponges, pelles, marteaux, zine, fer blanc, plomb en saumon, et, suivant les Conditions du Cahier des Charges et la liste dont on peut obtenir un exemplaire, contre paiement de 300 millimes au Bureau Central de Magasins Généraux à Boulo(Caire) et au Bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) chaque jour de. neuf beures du matin 1. p.m. les dimanches et jours fériés exceptés, on peut également y examiner les échantillons types et dessins.

Toute personne désirant prendre part à cette adjudication doit présenter avec no offre les échantillons demandés dans la liste qui est annexée au Cahier des Charges et doit déposer, au préalable dans la Cain Centro de l'Administration, une somme de L E. 25 (Vingt-cinq layres Égyptienne) titre de cautionnement provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette commojangu'coneurrence du dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agréée.

Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 30 (trente) millièmes sini que de reçu du versement du cautionnement provisoire. Elles seront adresSées par le poste sous pli recommandé :
Monsieur le Directeur Général
des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, Osire. et sous double enveloppe, intérieure portant la suscription suivante : 13S SEIS
"Offre pour fourniture d'articles divers."
Toate of re faite ou déposée postérieurement au jo ir et l'heure eudemus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la las basse, ni à donner suite aux los missions présentes. Elle nerve le droit de diviser commande. 30595-2-1 Le Caire, le 4 Juillet 1907.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
